editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

note.p: The title page is engraved and signed "Guliel[mus] Hole fecit". The second state of the imprint (see The Library, ser. 6, 8:152-6).

The subsidiary plays each have separate dated title pages. Of these, "Every man out of his humour", "Cynthia's revels", and "Poetaster" have title pages in varying states; see Greg for details. Pagination and register are continuous.
A number of sheets exist in two different settings, and certain of these appear to be reprints done much later; see Greg and "Studies in Bibliography" 40:106-20.
A second volume was published without general title page in 1631.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

div.p: PoÃ«taster, or his arraignment. A comical satire. Acted, in the year 1601. By the then children of Queen Elizabeth's chapel.

quote.l: Et mihi de nullo fama rubore placet.

div.p: London, printed by William Stansby, for Matthew Lownes.

div.head: To the virtuous, and my worthy friend, Mr. Richard Martin.
div.p: Sir, a thankful man owes a courtesy ever: the unthankful, but when he needs it. To make mine own mark appear, and show by which of these seals I am known, I send you this piece of what may live of mine; for whose innocence, as for the authors, you were once a noble and timely undertaker, to the greatest justice of this kingdom. Enjoy now the delight of your goodness; which is to see that prosper, you preserved: and posterity to owe the reading of that, without offence, to your name; which so much ignorance, and malice of the times, then conspired to have suppressed.

sp.speaker: Envy.
sp.l: Light,arising in the midst of the stage. I salute thee, but with wounded nerves:
Wishing thy golden splendour, pitchy darkness.
What's here? Th'arraignment? I: this, this is it,
That our sunk eyes have woken for, all this while:
Here will be subject for my snakes, and me.
Cling to my neck, and wrists, my loving worms,
And cast you round, in soft, and amorous folds,
Till I do bid, uncurl: then, break your knots,
Shoot out yourselves at length, as your forced stings
Would hide themselves within his maliced sides,
To whom I shall apply you. Stay! the shine
Of this assembly here offends my sight,
I'll darken that first, and outface their grace.
Wonder not, if I stare: these fifteen weeks
(So long as since the plot was but an embryon)
Have I, with burning lights, mixed vigilant thoughts,
In expectation of this hated play:
To which (At last) I am arrived as prologue.
Nor would I, you should look for other looks,
Gesture, or compliment from me, then what
Th'infected bulk of envy can afford:
For I am risse here with a covetous hope,
To blast your pleasures, and destroy your sports,
With wrestings, comments, applications,
spy-like suggestions, privy whisperings,
And thousand such promoting sleights as these.
Mark, how I will begin: the scene is, ha!
Rome? Rome? and Rome? Crack eye-strings, and your balls
Drop into earth; let me be ever blind.
I am prevented; all my hopes are crossed,
Checked, and abated; fie, a freezing sweat
Flows forth at all my pores, my entrails burn:
What should I do? Rome? Rome? O my vexed soul,
How might I force this to the present state?
Are there no players here? no poet-apes,
That come with basilisks eyes, whose forked tongues
Are steeped in venom, as their hearts in gall?
Either of these would help me; they could wrest,
Pervert, and poison all they hear, or see,
With senseless glosses, and allusions.
Now if you be good devils, fly me not.
You know what dear, and ample faculties
I have endowed you with: I'll lend you more.
Here, take my snakes among you, come, and eat,
And while the squeezed juice flows in your black jaws,
Help me to damn the author. Spit it forth
Upon his lines, and show your rusty teeth
At every word, or accent: or else choose
Out of my longest vipers, to stick down
In your deep throats; and let the heads come forth
At your rank mouths; that he may see you armed
With triple malice, to hiss, sting, and tear
His work, and him; to forge, and then declaim,
Traduce, corrupt, apply, inform, suggest:
Oh, these are gifts wherein your souls are blessed.
What? do you hide yourselves? will none appear?
None answer? what, doth this calm troop affright you?
Nay, than I do despair: down, sink again.
This travail is all lost with my dead hopes.
If in such bosoms, spite have left to dwell,
Envy is not on earth, nor scarce in hell.

div.head: The third sounding. Prologue.
div.l: Stay, monster, ere thou sink, thus on thy head
Set we our bolder foot; with which we tread
Thy malice into earth: so spite should die,
despised and scorned by noble industry.
If any muse why I salute the stage,
An armed prologue; know, 't is a dangerous age:
Wherein, who writes, had need present his scenes
Forty sold proof against the coniuring means
Of base detractors, and illiterate apes,
That fill up rooms in fair and formal shapes.
'Gainst these, have we put on this forc't defence:
Whereof the allegory and hid sense
Is, that a well erected confidence
Can fright their pride, and laugh their folly hence.
Here now, put case our author should, once more,
Swear that his play were good; he doth implore,
You would not argue him of arrogance:
Howe'er that common spawn of ignorance,
Our fry of writers, may beslime his fame,
And give his action that adulterate name.
Such full-blown vanity he more doth loath,
Then base dejection: there's a mean 'twixt both.
Which with a constant firmness he pursues,
As one, that knows the strength of his own muse.
And this he hopes all free souls will allow,
Others, that take it with a rugged brow,
Their moods he rather pities, then envies:
His mind it is above their injuries.

sp.l: Then, when this body falls in funeral fire,
My name shall live, and my best part aspire.
It shall go so.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Young master, master Ovid, do you hear? gods a me! away with your songs, and sonnets; and on with your gown and cap, quickly: here, here, your father will be a man of this room presently. Come, nay, nay, nay, nay, be brief. These verses too, a poison on 'em, I cannot abide 'em, they make me ready to cast, by the banks of Helicon. Nay look, what a rascally untoward thing this poetry is; I could tear 'em now.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Give me, how near's my father?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Heart a'man: get a lawbook in your hand, I will not answer you else. Why so: now there's some formality in you. By Jove, and three or four of the gods more, I am right of mine old master's humour for that; this villainous poetry will undo you, by the welkin.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: What, hast thou buskins on, Luscus, that thou swearest so tragically, and high?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: No, but I have boots on, sir, and so has your father too by this time: for he called for 'em, ere I came from the lodging.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Why? was he no readier?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: O no; and there was the mad skeldring captain, with the velvet arms, ready to lay hold on him as he comes down: he that presses every man he meets, with an oath, to lend him money, and cries; (Thou must do't, old boy, as thou art a man, a man of worship.)

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Who? Pantilius Tucca?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Ay, he: and I met little master Lupus, the tribune, going thither too.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Nay, and he be under their arrest, I may (With safety enough) read over my elegy, before he come.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: God's a me! What'll you do? why, young master, you are not Castalian mad, lunatic, frantic, desperate? ha?

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: What ailest thou, Luscus?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: God be with you, sir, I'll leave you to your poetical fancies, and furies. I'll not be guilty, I.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: Be not, good ignorance: I'm glad thou'rt gone:
For thus alone, our ear shall better judge
The hasty errors of our morning muse.
Ovid lib 1. Amo. ele 15. envy, why twit'st thou me, my time's spent ill?
And callest my verse, fruits of an idle quill?
Or that (Unlike the line from whence I sprung)
Wars dusty honours I pursue not young?
Or that I study not the tedious laws;
And prostitute my voice to every cause?
Thy scope is mortal; mine eternal fame:
Which through the world shall ever chant my name.
Homer will live, whilst Tenedos stands, and Ide,
Or, to the sea, sleet Simois doth slide:
And so shall Hesiod too, while vines do bear,
Or crooked sickles crop the ripened care.
Callimachus, though in invention low,
Shall still be sung: since he in art doth flow.
No loss shall come to Sophocles proud vain.
With sun, and moon, Aratus shall remain.
Whilst slaves be false, father's hard, and bawds be whorish,
Whilst harlots flatter, shall Menander flourish.
Ennius, though rude, and Accius high-reared strain,
A fresh applause in every age shall gain.
Of Varro's name, what ear shall not be told?
Of Jason's Argo? and the fleece of gold?
Then shall Lucretius lofty numbers die,
When earth, and seas in fire and flames shall fry.
Tytirus, tillage, Aenee shall be read,
Whilst Rome of all the conquered world is head.
Till Cupid's fires be out, and his bow broken,
Thy verses (Neat Tibullus) shall be spoken.
Our Gallus shall be known from East to West:
So shall Lycoris, whom he now loves best.
The suffering ploughshare, or the flint may wear:
But heavenly poesy no death can fear.
King's shall give place to it, and kingly shows,
The banks o'er which gold-bearing Tagus flows.
Kneel hinds to trash: me let bright Phoebus swell,
With cups full flowing from the muses well.
Frost-fearing myrtle shall impale my head,
And of sad lovers I'll be often read.
"Envy, the living, not the dead, doth bite:
" for after death all men receive their right.
Then, when this body falls in funeral fire,
My name shall live, and my best part aspire.

div.head: Act i. scene ii.
div.stage: Ovid Senior, Ovid junior, Luscus, Tucca, Lupus, Pyrgus.

sp.p: Your name shall live indeed, sir; you say true: but how infamously, how scorned and contemned in the eyes and ears of the best and gravest Romans, that you think not on: you never so much as dream of that. Are these the fruits of all my travail and expenses? is this the scope and aim of thy studies? are these the hopeful courses, wherewith I have so long flattered my expectation from thee? verses? poetry? Ovid, whom I thought to see the pleader, become Ovid the playmaker?

sp.speaker: Ovid junior
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: Ovid senior
sp.p: Yes, sir. I hear of a tragedy of yours coming forth for the common players there, called Medea. By my household-gods, if I come to the acting of it, I'll add one tragic part, more than is yet expected, to it: believe me when I promise it. What? shall I have my son a stager now? an ingle for players? A gull? A rook? A shot-clog? to make suppers, and be laughed at? Publius, I will set thee on the funeral pile, first.

sp.speaker: Ovid junior
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you to have patience.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Nay, this 'tis to have your ears dammed up to good counsel. I did augur all this to him aforehand, without poring into an ox's paunch for the matter, and yet he would not be scrupulous.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: How now, good man slave? what, roll powle? all rivals, rascal? why my master, of worship, dost hear? Are these thy best projects? is this thy designs and thy discipline, to suffer knaves to be competitors with commanders and gentlemen? are we parallels, rascal? are we parallels?

sp.speaker: Ovid. senior
sp.p: Sirrah, go get my horses ready. You'll still be prating.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Do, you perpetual stinkard, do, go, talk to tapsters and ostlers, you slave, they are i' your element, go: here be the emperor's captains, you raggamuffin rascal; and not your comrades.

sp.speaker: Lupu.
sp.p: Indeed, Marcus Ovid, these players are an idle generation, and do much harm in a state, corrupt young gentry very much, I know it: I have not been a tribune thus long, and observed nothing: besides, they will rob us, us, that are magistrates, of our respect, bring us upon their stages, and make us ridiculous to the plebeians; they will play you, or me, the wisest men they can come by still; me: only to bring us in contempt with the vulgar, and make us cheap.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Thou'rt in the right, my venerable cropshin, they will indeed: the tongue of the oracle never twanged truer. Your courtier cannot kiss his mistress slippers, in quiet, for 'em: nor your white innocent gallant pawn his revelling suit, to make his punk a supper. An honest decayed commander, cannot skelder, cheat, nor be seen in a bawdy house, but he shall be straight in one of their worm wood comedies. They are grown licentious, the rogues; libertines, flat libertines. They forget they are i' the statute, the rascals, they are blazoned there, there they are tricked, they and their pedigrees; they need no other heralds, I wiss.

sp.speaker: Ovid. senior
sp.p: methinks , if nothing else, yet this alone âª the very reading of the public edicts should fright thee from commerce with them; and give thee distaste enough of their actions. But this betrays what a student you are: this argues your proficiency in the law.

sp.speaker: Ovid. junior
sp.l: They wrong me, sir, and do abuse you more,
That blow your ears with these untrue reports.
I am not known unto the open stage,
Nor do I traffic in their theatres.
Indeed, I do acknowledge, at request
Of some near friends, and honourable Romans,
I have begun a poem of that nature.

sp.speaker: Ovid. senior
sp.p: You have, sir, a poem? and where is't? that's the law you study.

sp.speaker: Ovid. junior
sp.p: Cornelius Gallus borrowed it to read.

sp.speaker: Ovid. senior
sp.p:
Cornelius Gallus? There's another gallant, too, hath drunk of the same poison: and Tibullus, and Propertius. But these are gentlemen of means, and revenue now. Thou art a younger brother, and hast nothing, but thy bare exhibition: which I protest shall be bare indeed, if thou forsake not these unprofitable by-courses, and that timely too. Name me a professed poet, that his poetry did ever afford
him so much as a competency. Ay, your god of poets there (Whom all of you admire and reverence so much) Homer, he whose worm-eaten statue must not be spewed against, but with hallowed lips, and grovelling adoration, what was he? what was he?

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Marry, I'll tell thee, old swagger; he was a poor, blind, rhyming rascal, that lived obscurely up and down in booths, and tap-houses, and scarce ever made a good meal in his sleep, the whoreson hungry beggar.

sp.speaker: Ovid. senior
sp.p: He says well: nay, I know this nettles you now, but answer me; is't not true? you'll tell me his name shall live; and that (Now being dead) his works have eternised him, and made him divine but could this divinity feed him, while he lived? could his name feast him?

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Or purchase him a senator's revenue? could it?

sp.speaker: Ovid. senior
sp.p: Ay, or give him place in the commonwealth? worship, or attendants? make him be carried in his litter?

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Thou speakest sentences, old bias.

sp.speaker: Lupu.
sp.p: All this the law will do, young sir, if you'll follow it.

sp.speaker: Ovid. senior
sp.p: If he be mine, he shall follow and observe, what I will apt him too, or, I profess here openly, and utterly to disclaim in him.

sp.speaker: Ovid. junior
sp.l: Sir, let me crave you will, forgo these moods;
I will be any thing, or study any thing:
I'll prove the unfashioned body of the law
Pure elegance, and make her ruggedst strains
Ruin smoothly, as Propertius elegies.

sp.speaker: Ovid. senior
sp.l: Propertius elegies? good!

sp.speaker: Lupu.
sp.l: Nay, you take him too quickly, Marcus.

sp.speaker: Ovid. senior
sp.p: Why, he cannot speak, he cannot think out of poetry, he is bewitched with it.

sp.speaker: Lupu.
sp.p: Come, do not misprise him.

sp.speaker: Ovid. senior
sp.p: Misprise? Ay, marry, I would have him use some such words now: they have some touch, some taste of the law. He should make himself a style out of these, and let his Propertius elegies go by.

sp.speaker: Lupu.
sp.p: Indeed, young Publius, he that will now hit the mark, must shoot through the law we have no other planet reigns, and in that sphere, you may sit, and sing with angels. Why, the law makes a man happy, without respecting any other merit: a simple scholar, or none at all may be a lawyer.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: He tells thee true, my noble neophyte; my little grammaticaster, he does: it shall never put thee to thy mathematics, metaphysiques, philosophy, and I know not what supposed sufficiencies; if thou canst but have the patience to plod enough, talk, and make noise enough, be impudent enough, and 'tis enough.

sp.speaker: Lupu.
sp.p: Three books will furnish you.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: And the less art, the better: besides, when it shall be in the power of thy chevril conscience, to do right, or wrong, at thy pleasure, my pretty Alcibiades.

sp.speaker: Lupu.
sp.p: Ay, and to have better men than himself, by many thousand degrees, to observe him, and stand bare.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: True, and he to carry himself proud, and stately, and have the law on his side for't, old boy.

sp.speaker: Ovid. senior
sp.p: Well, the day grows old, gentlemen, and I must leave you. Publius, if thou wilt hold my favour, abandon these idle fruitless studies that so bewitch thee. Send Janus home his back-face again, and look only forward to the law: intend that. I will allow thee, what shall suit thee in the rank of gentlemen, and maintain thy society with the best: and under these conditions, I leave thee. My blessings light upon thee, if thou respect them: if not, mine eyes may drop for thee, but thine own heart will ache for itself; and so farewell. What, are my horses come?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Yes, sir, they are at the gate without.

sp.speaker: Ovid. senior
sp.p: That's well. Asinius Lupus, a word. Captain, I shall take my leave of you?

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: No, my little old boy, dispatch with cothurnus there: I'll attend thee, I â

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: To borrow some ten drachmas, I know his project.

sp.speaker: Ovid. senior
sp.p: Sir, you shall make me beholding to you. Now captain Tucca, what say you?

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Why, what should I say? or what can I say, my flower of the order? Should I say, thou art rich? or that thou art honourable? or wise? or valiant? or learned? or liberal? Why, thou art all these, and thou knowest it (My noble Lucullus) thou knowest it: come, be not ashamed of thy virtues, old stump. Honour's a good brooch to wear in a man's hat, at all times. Thou art the man of wars Maecenas, old boy. Why shouldst not thou be graced then by them, as well as he is by his poets? How now, my carrier, what news?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: The boy has stayed within for his cue, this half hour.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Come, do not whisper to me, but speak it out: what? it is no treason against the state, I hope, is't?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Yes, against the state of my master's purse.

sp.speaker: Pyrg.
sp.p: Sir, Agrippa desires you to forbear him till the next week: his moils are not yet come up.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: His moils? now the bots, the spavin, and the glanders, and some dozen diseases more, light on him, and his moils. What ha' they the yellows, his moils, that they come no faster? or are they foundered? ha? his moils ha' the staggers belike: ha' they?

sp.speaker: Pyrg.
sp.p: O no, sir: than your tongue might be suspected for one of his moils.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p:
He owes me almost a talon, and he thinks to bear it away with his moils, does he? Sirrah, you, nutcracker, go your ways to him again, and tell him I must ha' money, I: I cannot eat stones and turses, say. What, will he clem me, and my followers? Ask him, an' he will clem me: do, go. He would have me fry my jerkin, would he?
Away, setter, away. Yet, stay, my little tumbler: this old boy shall supply now. I will not trouble him, I cannot be importunate, I: I cannot be impudent.

sp.speaker: Pyrg.
sp.p: Alas, sir, no: you are the most maidenly blushing creature upon the earth.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Dost thou hear, my little six and fifty, or thereabouts? Thou art not to learn the humours and tricks of that old bald cheater, time: thou hadst not this chain for nothing. Men of worth have their chimaeras, as well as other creatures: and they do see monsters, sometimes: they do, they do, brave boy.

sp.speaker: Pyrg.
sp.p: Better cheap than he shall see you, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Thou must let me have six, six, drachmas, I mean, old boy; thou shalt do it: I tell thee, old boy, thou shalt, and in private too, dost thou see? Go, walk off: there, there. Six is the sum. Thy son's a gallant spark, and must not be put out of a sudden: come hither, Callinachus, thy father tells me thou art too poetical, boy, thou must not be so, thou must leave them, young novice, thou must, they are a sort of poor starved rascals; that are ever wrapped up in foul linen; and can boast of nothing but a lean visage, peering out of a seam-rent suit; the very emblems of beggary. No, dost hear? turn lawyer, thou shalt be my solicitor: 'tis right, old boy, is't?

sp.speaker: Ovid. senior
sp.p: You were best tell it, captain.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: No: fare thou well mine honest horseman, and thou old beaver. Pray thee Roman, when thou comest to town, see me at my lodging, visit me sometimes: thou shalt be welcome, old boy. Do not balk me, good swaggerer. Jove keep thy chain from pawning, go thy ways, if thou lack money, I'll lend thee some: I'll leave thee to thy horse, now. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Ovid. senior
sp.p: Farewell, good captain.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Boy, you can have but half a share now, boy.

sp.speaker: Ovid. senior
sp.p: 'Tis a strange boldness, that accompanies this fellow: come.

sp.speaker: Ovid. junior
sp.p: I'll give attendance on you, to your horse, sir, please you â

sp.speaker: Ovid. senior
sp.p: No: keep your chamber, and fall to your studies; do so: the gods of Rome bless thee.

sp.speaker: Ovid. junior
sp.l: And give me stomach to digest this law,
That should have followed sure, had I been he.
O sacred poesy, thou spirit of arts,
The soul of science, and the Queen of souls,
What profane violence, almost sacrilege,
Hath here been offered thy divinities!
That thine own guiltless poverty should arm
Prodigious ignorance to wound thee thus!
For thence, is all their force of argument
Drawn forth against thee; or from the abuse
of thy great powers in adulterate brains:
When, would men learn but to distinguish spirits,
And set true difference twixt those jaded wits
That run a broken pace for common hire,
And the high raptures of a happy muse
Born on the wings of her immortal thought,
That kicks at earth with a disdainful heel,
And bears at heaven gates with her bright hooves;
They would not then with such distorted faces,
And desperate censures stab at poesy.
They would admire bright knowledge, and their minds
Should never descend on so unworthy objects,
As gold, or titles: they would dread far more,
To be thought ignorant, then be known poor.
"The time was once, when wit drowned wealth: but now,
" your only barbarism is t'have wit, and want.
"No matter now in virtue who excels,
" he, that hath coin, hath all perfection else.
Ovid?

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: Who's there? Come in.

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.l: Good morrow, lawyer.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: Good morrow (Dear Tibullus) welcome: sit down.

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.l: Not I. What: so hard at it? Let's see, what's here?
Nay, I will see it â

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: Pray thee away â

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.l: If thrice in field, a man vanquish his foe,
'Tis after in his choice to serve, or no.
How now Ovid! Law â cases in verse?

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: In troth, I know not: they run from my pen
Unwittingly, if they be verse. What's the news abroad?

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.l: Off with this gown, I come to have thee walk.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: No, good Tibullus, I'm not now in case,
Pray let me alone.

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.l: How? not in case!
'Slight thou'rt in too much case, by all this law.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: Troth, if I live, I will new dress the law,
In sprightly poesies habiliments.

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.l: The hell thou wilt. What, turn law into verse?
Thy father has schooled thee, I see. Here, read that same.
There's subject for you: and if I mistake not,
A supersedeas to your melancholy.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: How! subscribed Julia! O, my life, my heaven!

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.l: Is the mood changed?

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: Music of wit! Note for th' harmonious spheres!
Celestial accents, how you ravish me!

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.l: What is it, Ovid?

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: That I must meet my Julia, the Princess Julia.

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Why, at â heart, I have forgotten: my passion so transports me.

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.l: I'll save your pains: it is at Albius house,
The jewellers, where the fair Lycoris lies.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: Who? Cytheris, Cornelius Gallus love?

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.l: Ay, he'll be there too, and my Plautia.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: And why not your Delia?

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.l: Yes, and your Corinna.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: True, but my sweet Tibullus, keep that secret:
I would not, for all Rome, it should be thought,
I veil bright Julia underneath that name:
Julia the gem, and jewel of my soul,
That takes her honours from the golden sky,
As beauty doth all lustre, from her eye.
The air respires the pure Elyzian sweets,
In which she breathes: and from her looks descend
The glories of the summer. Heaven she is,
Praised in herself above all praise: and he,
Which hears her speak, would swear the tuneful orbs
Turned in his zenith only.

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.l: Publius, thou'lt lose thyself.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: O, in no labyrinth, can I safelier err,
Then when I lose myself in praising her.
Hence law, and welcome, muses; though not rich,
Yet are you pleasing: let's be reconciled,
And now made one. Henceforth, I promise faith,
And all my serious hours to spend with you:
With you, whose music striketh on my heart,
And with bewitching tones steals forth my spirit,
In Julia's name; fair Julia: Julia's love
Shall be a law, and that sweet law I'll study,
The law, and art of sacred Julia's love:
All other objects will but abjects prove.

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.p: Come, we shall have thee as passionate, as Propertius, anon.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: O, how does my Sextus?

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.p: Faith, full of sorrow, for his Cynthia's death.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: What, still?

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.l: Still, and still more, his grieves do grow upon him,
As do his hours. Never did I know
An understanding spirit so take to heart
The common work of fate.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: O my Tibullus,
let us not blame him: for, against such chances,
The heartiest strife of virtue is not proof.
We may read constancy, and fortitude,
To other souls: but had ourselves been struck
With the like planet, had our loves (Like his)
Been ravished from us, by injurious death,
And in the height, and heat of our best days,
It would have cracked our sinews, shrunk our veins,
And made our very heartstrings jar, like his.
Come, let's go take him forth, and prove, if mirth
Or company will but abate his passion.

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.l: Content, and I implore the gods, it may.

sp.p: Master Crispinus, you are welcome: pray, use a stool, sir. Your cousin Cytheris will come down presently. We are so busy for the receiving of these courtiers here, that I can scarce be a minute with myself, for thinking of them: pray you sit, sir, pray you sit, sir.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I am very well, sir. Never trust me, but you are most delicately seated here, full of sweet delight and blandishment! an excellent air, an excellent air!

sp.speaker: Alei.
sp.p: Ay, sir, 'tis pretty air. These courtiers run in my mind still; I must look out: for Jupiter's sake, sit, sir. Or please you walk into the garden? There's a garden on the backside.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I am most strenuously well, I thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: Alei.
sp.p: Much good do you, sir.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Come, bring those perfumes forward a little, and strew some roses, and violets here; fie, here be rooms savour the most pitifully rank that ever I felt: I cry the god's mercy, my husband's in the wind of us.

sp.speaker: Alei.
sp.p: Why, this is good, excellent, excellent: well said, my sweet Chloe. Trim up your house most obsequiously.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: For Vulcanus sake, breathe somewhere else: in troth you overcome our perfumes exceedingly, you are too predominant.

sp.speaker: Alei.
sp.p: Hear but my opinion, sweet wife.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: A pin for your opinion. In sincerity, if you be âª thus fulsome to me in every thing, I'll be divorced; god's my body? you know what you were, before I married you; I was a gentlewoman born, I; I lost all my friends to be a citizen's wife; because I heard indeed, they kept their wives as fine as ladies; and that we might rule our husbands, like ladies; and do what we listed: do you think I would have married you, else?

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: I acknowledge, sweet wife, she speaks the best of any woman in Italy, and moves as mightily: which makes me, I had rather she should make bumps on my head, as big as my two singers, than I would offend her. But sweet wife â

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Yet again? Is't not grace enough for you, that I call you husband, and you call me wife: but you must still be poking me, against my will, to things?

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: But you know, wife; here are the greatest ladies, and gallantest gentlemen of Rome, to be entertained in our house now: and I would fain advise thee, to entertain them in the best sort, i'faith wife.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: In sincerity, did you ever hear a man talk so idly? You would seem to be master? You would have your spoke in my cart? you would advise me to entertain ladies, and gentlemen? because you can marshal your pack-needles, horsecombs, hobby-horses, and wall-candlesticks in your warehouse better than I; therefore you can tell how to entertain ladies, and gentlefolks better than I?

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: O my sweet wife, upbraid me not with that: "Gain savours sweetly from any thing; he that respects to get, must relish all commodities alike; and admit no difference betwixt oade, and frankincense; or the most precious balsamum, and a tar-barrel.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Marry fough: you sell snuffers too, if you be remembered, but I pray you let me buy them out of your hand; for I tell you true, I take it highly in snuff, to learn how to entertain gentlefolks, of you, at these years, i'faith. Alas man; there was not a gentleman came to your house i' your tother wife's time, I hope? nor a lady? nor music? nor masques? Nor you, nor your house were so much as spoken of, before I disbast myself, from my hood and my farthingale, to these bumrolls, and your whale-bone-bodies.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: Look here, my sweet wife; I am mum, my dear mummia, my balsamum, my spermaceti, and my very city of â she has the most best, true, feminine wit in Rome!

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I have heard so, sir; and do most vehemently desire to participate the knowledge of her fair features.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: Ah, peace; you shall hear more anon: be not seen yet, I pray you; not yet: observe.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: 'sbody, give husbands the head a little more, and they'll be nothing but head shortly; what's he there?

sp.speaker: Maid. 1.
sp.p: I know not forsooth.

sp.speaker: Maid. 2.
sp.p: Who would you speak with, sir?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I would speak with my cousin Cytheris.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: He is one forsooth would speak with his cousin Cytheris.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Is she your cousin, sir?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Yes in truth, forsooth, for fault of a better.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: She is a gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Or else she should not be my cousin, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Are you a gentleman born?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: That I am, lady; you shall see mine arms, if 't please you.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: No, your legs do sufficiently show you are a gentleman born, sir: for a man born upon little legs, is always a gentleman born.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Yet, I pray you, vouchsafe the sight of my arms, mistress; for I bear them about me, to have 'em seen: my name is Crispinus, or Crispinas indeed; which is well expressed in my arms, (A face crying in chief; and beneath it a bloody toe, between three thorns pungent.)

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Then you are welcome, sir; now you are a gentleman born, I can find in my heart to welcome you: for I am a gentlewoman born too; and will bear my head high enough, though 'twere my fortune to marry a tradesman.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: No doubt of that, sweet feature, your carriage shows it in any man's eye, that is carried upon you with judgement.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: he is still going in and out. dear wife, be not angry.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: God's my passion!

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: Hear me but one thing; let not your maids set cushions in the parlour windows; nor in the dining-chamber windows; nor upon stools, in either of them, in any case; for 'tis tavern-like; but lay them one upon another, in some outroom, or corner of the dining-chamber.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Go, go, meddle with your bedchamber only, or rather with your bed in your chamber, only; or rather with your wife in your bed only; or on my faith, I'll not be pleased with you only.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: Look here, my dear wife, entertain that gentleman kindly, I pray thee, â mum.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Go, I need your instructions indeed; anger me no more, I advise you. Citizen, quotha! she's a wise gentlewoman i'faith, will marry herself to the sin of the city.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: But this time, and no more (By heaven) wife: hang no pictures in the hall, nor in the dining-chamber, in any case, but in the gallery only, for 'tis not courtly else, of my word, wife.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: 'sprecious, never have done!

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: Wife. â

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Do I not bear a reasonable corrigible hand over him, Crispinus?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: By this hand, lady, you hold a most sweet hand over him.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: And then for the great gilt andirons? â

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Again! would the andirons were in your great guts, for me.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: I do vanish, wife.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p:
How shall I do, master Crispinus? here will be all the bravest ladies in court presently, to see your cousin Cytheris: o the
gods! how might I behave myself now, as to entertain them most courtly?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Marry, lady, if you will entertain them most courtly, you must do thus: as soon as ever your maid, or your man brings you word they are come; you must say (A pox on 'em, what do they here.) And yet when they come, speak them as fair, and give them the kindest welcome in words, that can be.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Is that the fashion of courtiers, Crispinus?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I assure you, it is, lady, I have observed it.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: For your pox, sir, it is easily hit on; but, 'tis not so easily to speak fair after, methinks ?

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: O wife, the coaches are come, on my word, a number of coaches, and courtiers.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: A pox on them: what do they here?

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: How now wife! wouldst thou not have 'em come?

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Come? come, you are a fool, you: he knows not the trick on't. Call Cytheris, I pray you: and good master Crispinus, you can observe, you say; let me entreat you for all the ladies behaviours, jewels, jests, and attires, that you marking as well as I, we may put both our marks together, when they are gone, and confer of them.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I warrant you, sweet lady; let me alone to observe, till I turn myself to nothing but observation. Good morrow cousin Cytheris.

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: Welcome kind cousin. What? are they come?

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: Ay, your friend Cornelius Gallus, Ovid, Tibullus, Propertius, with Julia the emperor's daughter, and the lady Plautia, are lighted at the door; and with them Hermogenes Tigellius, the excellent musician.

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: Come, let us go meet them, Chloe.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Observe, Crispinus.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: At a hair's breadth, lady, I warrant you.

div.head: Act ii. scene ii.
div.stage: Gallus, Ovid, Tibullus, Propertius, Hermogenes, Julia, Plautia, Cytheris, Chloe, Albius, Crispinus.

sp.p: Health to the lovely Chloe: you must pardon me, mistress, that I prefer this fair gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: I pardon, and praise you for it, sir; and I beseech your excellence, receive her beauties into your knowledge and favour.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p:
Cytheris, she hath favour, and behaviour, that commands as much of me: and sweet Chloe, know I do exceedingly love you, and
that I will approve in any grace my father the emperor may show you. Is this your husband?

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: For fault of a better, if it please your highness.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: God's my life! how he shames me!

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: Not a whit, Chloe, they all think you politic, and witty; wise women choose not husbands for the eye, merit, or birth, but wealth, and sovereignty.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Sir, we all come to gratulate, for the good report of you.

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.p: And would be glad to deserve your love, sir.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: My wife will answer you all, gentlemen; I'll come to you again presently.

sp.speaker: Plav.
sp.p: You have chosen you a most fair companion here, Cytheris, and a very fair house.

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: To both which, you and all my friends, are very welcome, Plautia.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: With all my heart, I assure your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Plav.
sp.p: Thanks, sweet mistress Chloe.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: You must needs come to court, lady, i'faith, and there be sure your welcome shall be as great to us.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: She will well deserve it, madame. I see, even in her looks, gentry, and general worthiness.

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.p: I have not seen a more certain character of an excellent disposition.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: Wife.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: O, they do so commend me here, the courtiers! what's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: For the banquet, sweet wife.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Yes; and I must needs come to court, and be welcome, the Princess says.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Ovid, and Tibullus, you may be bold to welcome your mistresses here.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: We find it so, sir.

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.p: And thank Cornelius Gallus.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Nay, my sweet Sextus, in faith thou art not sociable.

sp.speaker: Prop.
sp.l: In faith, I am not, Publius; nor I cannot.
Sick minds, are like sick men that burn with fevers,
Who when they drink, please but a present taste,
And after bear a more impatient fit.
Pray, let me leave you; I offend you all,
And myself most.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Stay, sweet Propertius.

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.l: You yield too much unto your grieves, and sat,
Which never hurts, but when we say it hurts us.

sp.speaker: Prop.
sp.l: O peace, Tibullus; your philosophy
Lends you too rough a hand to search my wounds.
Speak they of griefs, that know to sigh, and grieve;
the free and unconstrained spirit feels
No weight of my oppression.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: Worthy roman!
Methinks I taste his misery; and could
Sit down, and chide at his malignant stars.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.l: Methinks I love him, that he loves so truly.

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.l: This is the perfectest love, lives after death.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Such is the constant ground of virtue still.

sp.speaker: Plav.
sp.l: It puts on an inseparable face.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.l: Have you marked every thing, Crispinus?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Every thing, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.l: What gentlemen are these? do you know them?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Ay, they are poets, lady.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.l: Poets? they did not talk of me since I went, did they?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: O yes, and extolled your perfections to the heavens.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Now in sincerity, they be the finest kind of men, that ever I knew: poets? Could not one get the emperor to make my husband a poet, think you?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: No, lady, 'tis love, and beauty make poets: and since you like poets so well, your love, and beauties shall make me a poet.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: What shall they? and such a one as these?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Ay, and a better than these: I would be sorry else.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: And shall your looks change? and your hair change? and all, like these?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Why, a man may be a poet, and yet not change his hair, lady.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Well, we shall see your cunning: yet if you can change your hair, I pray, do.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: Ladies, and lordings, there's a slight banquet stays within for you, please you draw near, and accost it.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: We thank you, good Albius: but when shall we see those excellent jewels you are commended to have?

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: At your ladyship's service. I got that speech by seeing a play last-day, and it did me some grace now: I see, 'tis good to collect sometimes; I'll frequent these plays more than I have done, now I come to be familiar with courtiers.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Why, how now, Hermogenes? what ailest thou trow?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: A little melancholy, let me alone, pray thee.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Melancholy! how so?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: With riding: a plague on all coaches for me.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Is that hard-favoured gentleman a poet too; Cytheris?

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: No; this is Hermogenes, as humorous as a poet though: he is at musician.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: A musician? than he can sing.

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: That he can excellently; did you never hear him?

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: O no: will he be entreated, think you?

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p:
I know not. Friend, mistress Chloe would fain hear
Hermogenes sing: are you interested in him?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: No doubt, his own humanity will command him so far, to the satisfaction of so fair a beauty; but rather than fail, we'll all be suitors to him.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: cannot sing.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Pray thee, Hermogenes.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: 'cannot sing.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: For honour of this gentlewoman, to whose house, I know thou mayst be ever welcome.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: That he shall in truth, sir, if he can sing.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: This gentlewoman is wooing Hermogenes for a song.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: A song âª come, he shall not deny her. Hermogenes?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: 'cannot sing.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: No, the ladies must do it, he stays but to have their thanks acknowledged as a debt to his cunning.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: That shall not want: ourself will be the first shall promise to pay him more than thanks, upon a favour so worthily vouchsafed.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Thank you, madam, but 'will not sing.

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.p: Tut, the only way to win him, is to abstain from entreating him.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Do you love singing, lady?

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: O, passingly.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Entreat the ladies, to entreat me to sing then, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: I beseech your grace, entreat this gentleman to sing.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: That we will Chloe; can he sing excellently?

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: I think so, madam: for he entreated me, to entreat you, to entreat him to sing.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Heaven, and earth! would you tell that?

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: Good sir, let's entreat you to use your voice.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Alas, madam, I cannot in truth.

sp.speaker: Plav.
sp.p: The gentleman is modest: I warrant you, he sings excellently.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Hermogenes, clear your throat: I see by him, here's a gentleman will worthily challenge you.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Not I, sir, I'll challenge no man.

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.p: That's your modesty, sir: but we, out of an assurance of your excellency, challenge him in your behalf.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I thank you, gentlemen, I'll do my best.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Let that best be good, sir, you were best.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: O, this contention is excellent. What is't you sing, sir?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: If I freely may discover, etc. Sir, I'll sing that.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: One of your own compositions, Hermogenes.
He offers you vantage enough.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Nay truly, gentlemen, I'll challenge no man â: I can sing but one staff of the ditty neither.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: The better: Hermogenes himself will be entreated to sing the other.
sp.l: If I freely may discover,
What would please me in my lover:
I would have her fair, and witty,
Savouring more of court, than city;
A little proud, but full of pity:
Light, and humorous in her toying.
Oft building hopes, and soon destroying,
Long, but sweet in the enjoying,
Neither too easy, nor too hard:
All extremes I would have barred.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Believe me, sir, you sing most excellently.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: If there were a praise above excellence, the gentleman highly deserves it.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Sir, all this doth not yet make me envy you: for I know I sing better than you.

sp.speaker: Tibu.
sp.p: Attend Hermogenes, now.
sp.l: She should be allowed her passions,
So they were but used as fashions;
Sometimes froward, and then frowning,
Sometimes sickish, and then swooning,
Every fit, with change, still crowning.
Purely jealous, I would have her,
Then only constant when I crave her.
'Tis a virtue should not save her.
Thus, nor her delicates would cloy me,
Neither her peevishness annoy me.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: Nay, Hermogenes, your merit hath long since been both known, and admired of us.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: You shall hear me sing another: now will I begin.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: We shall do this gentleman's banquet too much wrong, that stays for us, ladies.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: 'Tis true: and well thought on, Cornelius Gallus.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Why 'tis but a short air, 'twill be done presently, pray stay; strike music.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: No, good Hermogenes: we'll end this difference within.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: 'Tis the common disease of all your musicians, hat they know no mean, to be entreated, either to begin, or end.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: Please you lead the way, gentles?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Thanks, good Albius.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: O, what a charm of thanks was here put upon me! O Jove, what a setting forth it is to a man, to have many courtiers come to his house! Sweetly was it said of a good old housekeeper; I had rather want meat, then want guests: specially, if they be courtly guests. For, never trust me, if one of their good legs made in a house, be not worth all the good cheer, a man can make them. He that would have fine guests, let him have a fine wife; he that would have a fine wife, let him come to me.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: By your kind leave, master Albius.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: What, you are not gone, master Crispinus?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Yes faith, I have a design draws me hence: pray sir, fashion mean excuse to the ladies.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: Will you not stay? and see the jewels, sir? I pay you stay.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Not for a million, sir, now; let it suffice, I must relinquish; and so in a word, please you to expiate this compliment.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: Mum.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: He presently go and ingle some broker, for a poet's gown, and bespeak a garland: and then jeweller, look to your best jewel i'faith.
Hot. li. 1. Sat. 9hmh? yes; I will begin an ode so: and it shall be to Maecenas.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: 'Slid, yonder's Horace! they say he's an excellent poet: Maecenas loves him. I'll fall into his acquaintance, if I can; I think he be composing, as he goes i' the street! ha? 't is a good humour, and he be: I'll compose too.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Swell me a bowl with lusty wine,
Till I may see the plump Lyaevs swim
Above the brim:
I drink, as I would wright,
In slowing measure, filled with flame, and spright.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Sweet Horace, Minerva, and the muses stand auspicious to thy designs. How farest thou, sweet man? frolic? rich? gallant? ha?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Not greatly gallant, sir, like my fortunes; well.
I'm bold to take my leave, sir, you'd naught else, sir, would you?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Troth, no, but I could wish thou didst know us, Horace, we are a scholar, I assure thee.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: A scholar, sir? I shall be covetous of your fair knowledge.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Gramercy, good Horace. Nay, we are new turned poet too, which is more; and a satirist too, which is more than that: I write just in thy vein, I. I am for your odes or your sermons, or any thing indeed; we are a gentleman besides: our name is Rufus Laberius Crispinus, wear a pretty Stoic too.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: To the proportion of your beard, I think it, sir.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: By Phoebus, here's a most neat fine street, is't not? I protest to thee, I am enamoured of this street now, more than of half the streets of some, again; 'tis so polite, and terse! There's the front of a building now. I study architecture too: if ever I should build, I'd have a house just of that prospective.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Doubtless, this gallants tongue has a good turn, when he sleeps.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I do make verses, when I come in such a street as this: oh your city-ladies, you shall ha'hem sit in every shop like the muses â offering you the Castalian dews, and the Thespian liquours, to as many as have but the sweet grace and audacity to â sip of their lips. Did you never hear any of my verses?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: No, sir (But I am in some fear, I must, now.)

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I'll tell thee some (If I can but recover 'em) I composed e'en now of a dressing, I saw a jeweller's wife wear, who indeed was a jewel herself: I prefer that kind of tire now, what's thy opinion, Horace?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: With your silver bodkin, it does well, sir.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I cannot tell, but it stirs me more than all your court-curls, or your spangles, or your tricks: I affect not these high gable-ends, these tuscane-tops, nor your coronets, nor your arches, nor your pyramids; give me a fine sweet â little delicate dressing, with a bodkin, as you say: and a mushroom, for all your other ornatures.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Is't not possible to make an escape from him?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I have remitted my verses, all this while, I think I ha' forget 'em.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Here's he, could wish you had else.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Pray Jove, I can entreat 'em of my memory.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: You put your memory to too much trouble, sir.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: No, sweet Horace, we must not ha' thee think so.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I cry you mercy; then, they are my ears
That must be tortured: well, you must have patience, ears.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Pray thee, Horace, observe.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Yes, sir: your satin sleeve begins to fret at the rug that is underneath it, I do observe: and your ample velvet bases are not without evident stains of a hot disposition, naturally.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: O â I'll die them into another colour, at pleasure: how many yards of velvet dost thou think they contain?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Heart! I have put him now in a fresh way
To vex me more: faith, sir, your mercer's book
Will tell you with more patience, than I can;
(For I am crossed, and so's not that, I think.)

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: 'Slight, these verses have lost me again: I shall not invite 'em to mind, now.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Rack not your thoughts, good sir; rather, defer it
to a new time; I'll meet you at your lodging,
Or where you please: till then, Jove keep you, sir.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Nay, gentle Horace, stay: I have it, now.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Yes, sir. Apollo, Hermes, Jupiter, look down upon me.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Rich was thy hap, sweet, dainty cap,
There to be placed:
Where thy smooth black, sleek white may smack,
And both be graced.
sp.p: White, is there usurped for her brow; her forehead: and then sleek, as the parallel to smooth, that went before. A kind of paranomasy, or agnomination: do you conceive, sir?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Excellent. Troth, sir, I must be abrupt, and leave you.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Why, what haste hast thou? pray thee, stay a little: thou shalt not go yet, by Phoebus.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: I shall not? what remedy? Fie, how I sweat with suffering!

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: And then â

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Pray, sir, give me leave to wipe my face a little.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Yes, do, good Horace.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Thank you, sir.
Death! I must crave his leave to piss anon;
Or that I may go hence with half my teeth:
I am in some such fear. This tyranny
Is strange, to take mine ears up by commission,
(Whether I will or no) and make them stalls
To his lewd soloecismes, and worded trash.
Happy thou, bold Bolanus, now, I say;
Whose freedom, and impatience of this fellow,
Would, long ere this, have called him fool, and fool,
And rank, and tedious fool, and have flung jests
As hard as stones, till thou hadst pelted him
Out of the place: whilst my tame modesty
Suffers my wit be made a solemn ass
To bear his fopperies â

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Horace, thou art miserably affected to be gone, I see. But â pray thee, let's prove, to enjoy thee awhile: thou hast no business, I assure me. Whether is thy journey directed? ha?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Sir, I am going to visit a friend, that's sick.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: A friend? What's he? do not I know him?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: No, sir, you do not know him; and 'tis not the worse for him.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: What's his name? where's he lodged?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Where, I shall be fearful to draw you out of your way, sir; a great way hence: pray, sir, let's part.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Nay, but where is't? I pray thee, say.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: On the far side of all Tiber yonder, by Caesar's gardens.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: O, that's my course directly; I am for you. Come, go: why standest thou?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Yes, sir: marry, the plague is in that part of the city; I had almost forgotten to tell you, sir.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Fow: it's no matter, I fear no pestilence, I ha' not offended Phoebus.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I have, it seems; or else this heavy scourge
Could never have lighted on me â

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Come, along.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: I am to go down some half mile, this way, sir, first, to speak with his physician: and from thence to his apothecary, where I shall stay the mixing of divers drugs â

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Why, it's all one. I have nothing to do, and I love not to be idle, I'll bear thee company. How callest thou the apothecary?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: O, that I knew a name would fright him now. Sir Rhadamanthus, Rhadamanthus, sir.
There's one so called, is a just judge, in hell,
And doth inflict strange vengeance on all those,
That (Here on earth) torment poor patient spirits.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: He dwells at the three fairies, by Janus temple?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Your apothecary does, sir.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Heart, I owe him money for sweet meats, and he has laid to arrest me, I hear: but â

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Sir, I have made a most solemn vow: I will never bail any man.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Well then, I'll swear, and speak him fair, if the worst come. But his name is Minos, not Rhadamanthus, Horace.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: That may be, sir: I but guest at his name by his sign. But your Minos is a judge too, sir?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I protest to thee, Horace (Do but taste me once) if I do know myself, and mine own virtues truly, thou wilt not make that esteem of Varius, or Virgil, or Tibullus, or any of 'em indeed, as now in thy ignorance thou dost; which I am content to forgive: I would fain see, which of these could pen more verses in a day, or with more facility than I; or that could court his mistress, kiss her hand, make better sport with her fan, or her dog â

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: I cannot bail you yet, sir.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Or that could move his body more gracefully, or dance better you should see me, were it not i' the street â

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Nor yet.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Why, I have been a reveller, and at my cloth of silver suit, and my long stocking, in my time, and will be again â

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: If you may be trusted, sir.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: And then for my singing, Hermogenes himself envies me; that is your only master of music you have in Rome.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Is your mother living, sir?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Au: convert thy thoughts to somewhat else, I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: You have much of the mother in you, sir: your father is dead?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Ay, I thank Jove, and my grandfather too and all my kinsfolks, and well composed in their urns.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: The more their happiness; that rest in peace,
Free from th'abundant torture of thy tongue;
Would I were with them too.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: What's that, Horace?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I now remember me, sir, of a sad fate
A cunning woman, one Sabella sung,
When in her urn, she cast my destiny,
I being but a child

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: What was't I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: She told me, I should surely never perish
By famine, poison, or the enemy's sword;
The hectic fever, cough, or pleurisy,
Should never hurt me; nor the tardy gout:
But in my time, I should be once surprised,
By a strong tedious talker, that should vex
And almost bring me to consumption.
Therefore (If I were wise) she warned me shun
All such long-winded monsters, as my bane:
For if I could but scape that one discourser,
I might (No doubt) prove an old aged man.
By your leave, sir?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Tut, tut: abandon this idle humour, 'tis nothing but melancholy. Fore Jove, now I think on't, I am to appear in court here, to answer to one that has me in suit; sweet Horace, go with me, this is my hour: if I neglect it, the law proceeds against me. Thou art familiar with these things, pray thee, if thou lovest me, go.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Now, let me die, sir, if I know your laws;
Or have the power to stand still half so long
In their loud courts, as while a case is argued.
Besides, you know, sir, where I am to go,
And the necessity â

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: 'Tis true: â

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: I hope the hour of my release be come: he will (Upon this consideration) discharge me, sure.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Troth, I am doubtful, what I may best do; whether to leave thee, or my affairs, Horace?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: O Jupiter, me, sir; me, by any means: I beseech you, me, sir.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: No saith, I'll venture those now: thou shalt see I love thee, come Horace.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p:
Nay then, I am desperate: I follow you, sir. 'tis hard
contending with a man that overcomes thus.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: And how deals Maecenas with thee? liberally? ha?
Is he openhanded? bountiful?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: He's still himself, sir.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Troth, Horace, thou art exceeding happy in thy friends and acquaintance; they are all most choice spirits, and of the first rank of Romans: I do not know that poet, I protest, has used his fortune more prosperously, than thou hast. If thou wouldst bring me known to Maecenas, I should second thy desert well; thou shouldst find a good sure assistant of me: one, that would speak all good of thee in thy absence, and be content with the next place, not envying thy reputation with thy patron. Let me not live, but I think thou and I (In a small time) should list them all out of favour, both Virgil, Varius, and the best of them; and enjoy him wholly to ourselves.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Gods, you do know it, I can hold no longer;
This breeze hath pricked my patience: sir, your silkenness
Clearly mistakes Maecenas, and his house;
To think, there breathes a spirit beneath his roof,
Subject unto those poor affections
Of undermining envy, and detraction,
Moods, only proper to base grovelling minds:
That place is not in Rome, I dare affirm,
More pure, or free, from such low common evils.
There's no man grieved, that this is thought more rich,
Or this more learned; each man hath his place,
And to his merit, his reward of grace:
Which with a mutual love they all embrace.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: You report a wonder! 'tis scarce credible, this.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I am no torture, to enforce you to believe it, but 'tis so.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Why, this inflames me with a more ardent desire to be his, then before: but, I doubt I shall find the entrance, to his familiarity, somewhat more than difficult, Horace.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Tut, you'll conquer him, as you have done me; there's no standing out against you, sir, I see that. Either your importunity, or the intimation of your good parts; or â

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Nay, I'll bribe his porter, and the grooms of his chamber; make his doors open to me that way, first: and then, I'll observe my times. Say, he should extrude me his house today; shall I therefore desist, or let fall my suit, tomorrow? No: I'll attend him, follow him, meet him? i' the street, the high ways, run by his coach, never leave him. What? Man hath nothing given him, in this life, without much labour.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: And impudence.
Archer of heaven, Phoebus, take thy bow,
And with a full drawn shaft, nail to the earth
This Python; that I may yet run hence, and live:
or brawny Hercules, do thou come down,
And (Though thou mak'st it up thy thirteenth labour)
Rescue me from this Hydra of discourse, here.
Horace, well met.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: O welcome, my reliever,
Aristius, as thou lovest me, ransom me.

sp.speaker: Aris.
sp.l: What ailest thou, man?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: 'Death, I am seized on here
By a land-remora, I cannot stir;
Not move, but as he please.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Wilt thou go, Horace?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: 'Heart! he cleaves to me like Alcides shirt,
Tearing my flesh, and sinews; o, I ha' been vexed
And tortured with him, beyond forty fevers.
For Jove's sake, find some means, to take me from him.

sp.speaker: Aris.
sp.l: Yes, I will: but I'll go first, and tell Maecenas.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Come, shall we go?

sp.speaker: Aris.
sp.l: The jest will make his eyes run, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Nay, Aristius?

sp.speaker: Aris.
sp.l: Farewell, Horace.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: 'death! will a' leave me? Fuscus Aristius, do you hear? Gods of Rome! you said, you had somewhat to say to me, in private.

sp.speaker: Aris.
sp.p: Ay, but I see, you are now employed with that gentleman: 'twere offence to trouble you. I'll take some fitter opportunity, farewell.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Mischief, and torment! O, my soul, and heart,
How are you cramped with anguish! Death itself
Brings not the like convulsions. O, this day,
That ever I should view thy tedious face â

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Horace, what passion? what humour is this?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Away, good prodigy, afflict me not.
(A friend, and mock me thus!) never was man
So left under the axe â how now.

sp.p: That's he, in the embroidered hat, there, with the ash-coloured feather: his name is Laberius Crispinus.

sp.speaker: Lict.
sp.p: Laberius Crispinus; I arrest you in the emperor's name.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Me, sir? do you arrest me?

sp.speaker: Lict.
sp.p: Ay, sir, at the suit of master Minos the pothecary.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Thanks, great Apollo: I will not slip thy favour offered me in my escape, for my fortunes.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Master Minos? I know no master Minos. Where's Horace? Horace? Horace?

sp.speaker: Mino.
sp.p: Sir, do not you know me?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: O yes; I know you, master Minos: cry you mercy. But Horace? God's me, is he gone?

sp.speaker: Mino.
sp.p: Ay, and so would you too, if you knew how. Officer, look to him.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Do you hear, master Minos? pray let's be used like a man of our own fashion. By Janus, and Jupiter, I meant to have paid you next week, every drachma. Seek not to eclipse my reputation, thus vulgarly.

sp.speaker: Mino.
sp.p: Sir, your oaths cannot serve you, you know I have forborn you long.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I am conscious of it, sir. Nay, I beseech you, gentlemen, do not exhale me thus; remember 'tis but for sweet meats â

sp.speaker: Lict.
sp.p: Sweet meat must have sour sauce, sir. Come along.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Sweet, master Minos: I am forfeited to eternal disgrace, if you do not commiserate. Good officer, be not so officious.

div.head: Act iii. Scene iiii.
div.stage: Tucca, Pyrgus, Minos, lictors, Crispinus, Histrio, Demetrius.

sp.p: Why, how now, my good brace of bloodhounds? whither do you drag the gent'man? you mongrels, you curs, you bandogs, we are captain Tucca, that talk to you, you inhumane pilchers.

sp.speaker: Mino.
sp.p: Sir, he is their prisoner.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Their pestilence. What are you, sir?

sp.speaker: Mino.
sp.p: A citizen of Rome, sir.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Then you are not far distant from a fool, sir.

sp.speaker: Mino.
sp.p: A pothecary, sir.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: I knew thou wast not a physician; fough: out of my nostrils, thou stinkest of lotium, and the syringe: away, quacksalver. Follower, my sword.

sp.speaker: Pyrg.
sp.p: Here, noble leader, you'll do no harm with it: I'll trust you.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Do you hear, you, goodman slave? hook, ram, rogue, catchpole, lose the gent'man, or by my velvet arms â

sp.speaker: Lict.
sp.p: What will you do, sir? the officer strikes up his heels.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Kiss thy hand, my honourable active varlet: and embrace thee, thus.

sp.speaker: Pyrg.
sp.p: O patient metamorphosis!

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: My sword, my tall rascal.

sp.speaker: Lict.
sp.p: Nay, soft, sir: some wiser than some.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: What? and a wit to! By Pluto, thou must be cherished, slave; here's three drachmas for thee: hold.

sp.speaker: Pyrg.
sp.p: There's half his lendings gone.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Give me.

sp.speaker: Lict.
sp.p: No, sir, your first word shall stand: I'll hold all.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Nay, but, rogue â

sp.speaker: Lict.
sp.p: You would make a rescue of our prisoner, sir, you?

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Ay, a rescue? away inhumane varlet. Come, come, I never relish above one jest at most; do not disgust me: sirrah, do not. Rogue, I tell thee, rogue, do not.

sp.speaker: Lict.
sp.p: How, sir? rogue?

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Ay, why! thou art not angry, rascal? art thou?

sp.speaker: Lict.
sp.p: I cannot tell, sir, I am little better, upon these terms.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Ha! gods, and fiends! why, dost hear? rogue, thou, give me thy hand; I say unto thee, thy hand: rogue. What? dost not thou know me? not me, rogue? not captain Tucca, rogue?

sp.speaker: Mino.
sp.p: Come: pray surrender the gentleman his sword, officer; we'll have no fighting here.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: What's thy name?

sp.speaker: Mino.
sp.p: Minos, an't please you.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Minos? come, hither, Minos; thou art a wise fellow, it seems: let me talk with thee.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Was ever wretch so wretched, as unfortunate I?

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Thou art one of the centum-viri, old boy, art' not?

sp.speaker: Mino.
sp.p: No, indeed, master captain.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Go to, thou shalt be, then: I'll ha' thee one, Minos. Take my sword from those rascals, dost thou see? go, do it: I cannot attempt with patience. What does this gentleman owe thee, little Minos?

sp.speaker: Mino.
sp.p: Fourscore sesterties, sir.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: What? no more? Come, thou shalt release him, Minos: what, I'll be his bail, thou shalt take my word, old boy, and cashier these furies: thou shalt do't, I say, thou shalt, little Minos, thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Yes, and as I am a gentleman, and a reveller, I'll make a piece of poetry, and absolve all, within these five days.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Come, Minos is not to learn how to use a gent'man of quality, I know; my sword: if he pay thee not, I will, and I must, old boy. Thou shalt be my apothecary too: hast good eringoes, Minos?

sp.speaker: Mino.
sp.p: The best in Rome, sir.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Go too then â vermin, know the house.

sp.speaker: Pyrg.
sp.p: I warrant you, colonel.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: For this gentleman, Minos?

sp.speaker: Mino.
sp.p: I'll take your word, captain.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Thou hast it, my sword â

sp.speaker: Mino.
sp.p: Yes, sir: but you must discharge the arrest, master Crispinus.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: How, Minos? look in the gentleman's face, and but read his silence. Pay, pay; 'tis honour, Minos.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: By Jove, sweet captain, you do most infinitely endear, and oblige me to you.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Tut, I cannot compliment, by Mars: but Jupiter love me, as I love good words, and good clothes, and there's an end. Thou shalt give my boy that girdle, and hangers, when thou hast worn them a little more â

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: O Jupiter! Captain, he shall have them now, presently: please you to be acceptive, young gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pyrg.
sp.p: Yes, sir, fear not; I shall accept: I have a pretty foolish humour of taking, if you knew all.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Not now, you shall not take, boy.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: By my truth, and earnest, but he shall, captain, by your leave.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Nay, and a' swear by his truth, and earnest, take it boy: do not make a gent'man forsworn.

sp.speaker: Lict.
sp.p: Well, sir, there is your sword; but thank master Minos: you had not carried it as you do, else.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Minos is just, and you are knaves, and â

sp.speaker: Lict.
sp.p: What say you, sir?

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Pass on, my good scoundrel, pass on, I honour thee: but, that I hate to have action with such base rogues as these; you should ha' seen me unrip their noses now, and have sent 'em to the next barbers, to stitching: for, do you see â I am a man of humour, and I do love the varlets, the honest varlets; they have wit, and valour: and are indeed good profitable â errant rogues, as any live in an empire. Dost thou hear, poetaster? second me. Stand up (Minos) close, gather, yet, so. Sir (Thou shalt have a quarter share, be resolute) you shall, at my request, take Minos by the hand, here, little Minos, I will have it so; all friends, and a health: be not inexorable. And thou shalt impart the wine, old boy, thou shalt do't, little Minos, thou shalt: make us pay it in our physic. What? we must live, and honour the gods, sometimes; now Bacchus, now Comus, now Priapus: every god, a little. What's he, that stalks by, there? boy, Pyrgus, you were best let him pass, sirrah; do, ferret, let him pass, do.

sp.speaker: Pyrg.
sp.p: 'Tis a player, sir.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p:
A player? Call him, call the lousy slave hither: what, will he sail by, and not once strike, or veil to a man of war? ha? do you
hear? you, player, rogue, stalker, come back here: no respect to men of worship, you slave? What, you are proud, you rascal, are you proud? ha? you grow rich, do you? and purchase, you twopenny tear-mouth? you have fortune, and the good year on your side, you stinkard? you have? you have?

sp.speaker: Hist.
sp.p: Nay, sweet captain, be confined to some reason; I protest I saw you not, sir.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: You did not? where was your sight, Oedipus? you walk with hare's eyes, do you? I'll ha' 'em glazed, rogue; and you say the word, they shall be glazed for you: come, we must have you turn fiddler again, slave, get a base violin at your back, and march in a tawny coat, with one sleeve, to goose-fair, and then you'll know us; you'll see us then; you will, Gulch, you will? Then, wil't please your worship to have any music, captain?

sp.speaker: Hist.
sp.p: Nay, good captain.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: What? do you laugh, Owlglass? death, you presumptuous varlet, I am none of your fellows: I have commanded a hundred and fifty such rogues, I.

sp.speaker: 1. Pyr.
sp.p: Ay, and most of that hundred and fifty, have been leaders of a legion.

sp.speaker: Hist.
sp.p: If I have exhibited wrong, I'll tender satisfaction, captain.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Sayest thou so, honest vermin? Give me thy hand, thou shalt make us a supper one of these nights.

sp.speaker: Hist.
sp.p: When you please, by Jove, captain, most willingly.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Dost thou swear? tomorrow then; say, and hold slave. There are some of you players honest gent'man-like scoundrels, and suspected to ha' some wit, as well as your poets; both at drinking, and breaking of jests: and are companions for gallants. A man may skelder ye, now and then, of half a dozen shillings, or so. Dost thou not know that Pantalabus there?

sp.speaker: Hist.
sp.p: No, I assure you, captain.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Go, and be acquainted with him, then; he is a gent'man, parcel-poet, you slave: his father was a man of worship, I tell thee. Go, he pens high, lofty, in a new stalking strain; bigger than half the rhymers i' the town, again: he was born to fill thy mouth, Minotaurus, he was: he will teach thee to tear, and rend, rascal, to him, cherish his muse, go: thou hast forty, forty, shillings, I mean, stinkard, give him in earnest, do, he shall write for thee, slave. If he pen for thee once, thou shalt not need to travel, with thy pumps full of gravel, any more, after a blind jade and a hamper: and stalk upon boards, and barrel heads, to an old cracked trumpet â

sp.speaker: Hist.
sp.p: Troth, I think I ha' not so much about me, captain.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p:
It's no matter: give him what thou hast: stiff toe, I'll give my word for the rest: though it lack a shilling, or two, it skills not: go, thou art an honest shifter, I'll ha' the statute repealed for thee. Minos,
must tell thee, Minos, thou hast dejected you gent'mans spirit exceedingly: dost observe? dost note, little Minos?

sp.speaker: Mino.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: Go to then, raise; recover, do. Suffer him not to droop, in prospect of a player, a rogue, a stager: put twenty into his hand, twenty, sesterces, I mean, and let nobody see: go, do it, the work shall commend itself, be Minos, I'll pay.

sp.speaker: Mino.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, captain.

sp.speaker: 2. Pyr.
sp.p: Do not we serve a notable shark?

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: And what new matters have you now afoot, sirrah? ha? I would fain come with my cockatrice one day, and see a play; if I knew when there were a good bawdy one: but they say, you ha' nothing but humours, revels, and satyrs, that gird, and fart at the time, you slave.

sp.speaker: Hist.
sp.p: No, I assure you, captain, not we. They are on the other side of Tiber: we have as much ribaldry in our plays, as can be, as you would wish, captain: all the sinners, i' the suburbs, come, and applaud our action, daily.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: I hear, you'll bring me of the stage there; you'll play me, they say: I shall be presented by a sort of copper-laced scoundrels of you: life of Pluto, and you stage me, stinkard; your mansions shall sweat for't, your tabernacles, varlets, your globes, and your triumphs.

sp.speaker: Hist.
sp.p: Not we, by Phoebus, captain âª do not do us imputation without desert.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.p: I will not, my good twopenny rascal: reach me thy neufe. Dost hear? What wilt thou give me a week, for my brace of beagles, here, my little point-trussers? you shall ha' them act among ye. Sirrah, you, pronounce. Thou shalt hear him speak, in King Darius' doleful strain.

sp.speaker: 1. Pyr.
sp.l: O doleful days! O direful deadly dump!
O wicked world! and worldly wickedness!
How can I hold my fist from crying, thump,
In rue of this right rascal wretchedness!

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.l: In an amorous vain now, sirrah, peace.

sp.speaker: 1. Pyr.
sp.l: O, she is wilder, and more hard, withal,
Then beast, or bird, or tree, or stony wall.
Yet might she love me, to uprear her state:
Ay, but perhaps, she hopes some nobler mate.
Yet might she love me, to content her sire:
Ay, but her reason masters her desire.
Yet might she love me as her beauty's thrall:
Ay, but I fear, she cannot love at all.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.l: Now, the horrible fierce soldier, you, sirrah.

sp.speaker: 1. Pyr.
sp.l: What? will I brave thee? Ay, and beard thee too.
A roman spirit scorns to bear a brain,
So full of base pusillanimity.

sp.speaker: Demet. Hist.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.l: Nay, thou shalt see that, shall ravish thee anon: prick up thine ears, stinkard: the ghost, boys.

sp.speaker: 1. Pyr.
sp.l: Vindicta.

sp.speaker: 2. Pyr.
sp.l: Timoria.

sp.speaker: 1. Pyr.
sp.l: Vindicta.

sp.speaker: 2. Pyr.
sp.l: Timoria.

sp.speaker: 1. Pyr.
sp.l: Veni.

sp.speaker: 2. Pyr.
sp.l: Veni.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.l: Now, thunder, sirrah, you, the rumbling player.

sp.speaker: 1. Pyr.
sp.l: Ay, but somebody must cry (Murder) then, in a small voice.

sp.speaker: Tucc.
sp.l: Your fellow-sharer, there, shall do't; cry, sirrah, cry.

sp.speaker: 1. Pyr.
sp.l: Murder, murder.

sp.speaker: 2. Pyr.
sp.l: Who calls out murder? lady, was it you?
